bibl.idno: The Philip S. Hench Walter Reed/Yellow Fever Collection [manuscript] / [collected by] Philip S. Hench ; HEALTHSCI MS-1.

div1.p: This Mayo Clinic newspaper includes a notice that Hench will attend the dedication of Washington and Jefferson College's Lazear Memorial Building, and will be awarded an honorary degree.

div1.head: The Clinic Bulletin, October 23, 1940
div1.p:
MEETING OF GENERAL STAFF TO BE HELD
AT MAYO CIVIC AUDITORIUM

The meeting of General Staff will be held in
Mayo Civic Auditorium at 8:00 o'clock this evening.
Admission will be by ticket. Tickets have been sent
to members of the staff and to fellows; additional
tickets for guests and friends may be secured from
Miss Fitzgerald.

The meeting will be given over to the ceremonies
connected with the twenty-fifth anniversary of the
establishment of the Mayo Foundation. Dr. D. C.
Balfour, Director of the Mayo Foundation, will pre-
side. Dr. L. D. Powell, President of the Alumni
Association, will give the presidential address; other
addresses will be given by Dr. L. B. Wilson, Emeritus
Director, Mr. T. C. Blegen, Dean of the Graduate
School of the University of Minnesota, Mr. Guy
Stanton Ford, President of the University of Minne-
sota, and Mr. G. E. Vincent, President of the Uni-
versity of Minnesota at the time the Foundation was
established.
PATHOLOGIC CONFERENCE

The Pathologic Conference will be held from 7:00
to 7:45 o'clock this evening in the Assembly Room.
Note the change in time.
PUBLIC HEALTH LECTURE

Dr. O. L. Kirklin will give the public health lec-
ture Thursday at 7:30 p.m. in the Clinic lobby. His
subject is “Goiter.”
SEMINARS

The medical seminar at the Colonial Hospital will
meet at 8:15 a.m. Friday in the surgical waiting
room. Dr. Watkins will conduct the seminar.

The medical seminar at St. Mary's Hospital will
meet at 8:00 a.m. Saturday in the sun room, second
floor South. Dr. Amberg will conduct the seminar.
COMMUNITY CHEST

All contributions for the Community Chest should
be turned in as soon as possible as the campaign
will be officially closed this evening.
TICKETS FOR ALUMNI ASSOCIATION BANQUET

Tickets for the annual banquet of the Alumni As-
sociation of the Mayo Foundation may be obtained
from Miss Fitzgerald, the Alumni Headquarters in
the Main Lobby of the Hotel Kahler or the Business
Office at the Clinic. Residents are urged to obtain
their tickets for the banquet as soon as possible.
LOST

A copy of “The heart sounds in normal and patho-
logical conditions” by Orias and Braun-Menendez
has been lost. Will the finder please call Room 1040.
NOTICE

The scientific German class will not meet tomor-
row evening. The class will meet as usual Monday
evening, October 28, at 8:00 oclock in Room 1536.

SCIENTIFIC AND GENERAL PROGRAM FOR THE
TWENTY-SECOND ANNUAL MEETING OF THE
ALUMNI ASSOCIATION OF THE MAYO
FOUNDATION FOR MEDICAL EDUCATION
AND RESEARCH

Wednesday, October 23
Morning program, 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 m.
Registration--Alumni Headquarters. Lounge, Main Lobby, Hotel
Kahler.
Surgical clinics--See daily lists at Miss Fitzgerald's desk in
Clinic and Alumni Headquarters.
Medical rounds--The following physicians will be making rounds
and will welcome small groups of alumni.
Medical rounds--St. Mary's Hospital
Diseases of the colon ______________E. G. Wakefield
Obstetrics and gynecology ___________L. M. Randall
Pediatrics _______________________R. L. J. Kennedy
Medical clinics--Worrall Hospital
Cardiac service ____________________A. R. Barnes
General medicine ___________________A. E. Brown
Medical clinics--Kahler
Goiter service _____________________S. F. Haines
and A. C. Davis

Afternoon Session
Plummer Hall
2:15-3:45 p.m.--Symposium on cardiovascular disease
Orthostatic hypotension and tachycardia__A. R. MacLean
The recording of heart sounds ________________T. J. Dry
Postoperative venous thrombosis___________E. V. Allen and
L. A. Smith
The present status of heparin ____________J. T. Priestley
Abnormalities in electrocardiographic tracings of
noncardiac origin ________________________H. R. Burchell
Renal hypertension ______N. W. Barker, W. F. Braasch
and Waltman Walters
3:45-5:00 p.m.--Motion picture demonstration of surgical pro-
cedures
Traumatic injuries of the face ___________J. B. Erich and
G. B. New
Radical amputation of the breast ____S. W. Harrington
Transurethral resection ______________G. J. Thompson
Epidermoid tumor (intradiploic and intracranial)
__________________________J. G. Love
Surgical treatment of lymphedema _______H. B. Macey
Evening Session

See program for staff meeting elsewhere in the Clinic Bulletin.
Open House at Mayo Foundation House for members of the
Alumni Association, Fellows of the Mayo Foundation and
their wives will be held following the meeting of General
Staff.

Thursday, October 24
Morning program, 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 m.
Surgical clinics--See daily lists at Miss Fitzgerald's desk in
Clinic and Alumni Headquarters.
Medical clinics (Assembly Room)
The value of sternal aspiration in the diagnosis of
hematologic disease _____C. H. Watkins and associates
Deficiency diseases __________________P. W. Brown
Gout _______________________________C. H. Slocumb
Dermatologic clinic ______P. A. O'Leary and associates
Metabolic diseases _______R. M. Wilder and associates
Ulcer and gastritis ____A. B. Rivers and H. J. Moersch

Afternoon Session
1:45 p.m.--Business meeting, Kahler Dining Room.
Plummer Hall
3:00 p.m.--Histaminase therapy in vascular headaches and
Ménière's disease ________________________B. T. Horton
The injection of peripheral nerves for relief of
neural pain ________________________E. B. Tuohy
Stilbestrol therapy __________________L. M. Randall
Vaginal hysterectomy __________________J. M. Waugh
Present status of surgery of the spleen __J. deJ. Pemberton
Significant statistics on gastric resection____ H. K. Gray
(Waltman Walters) and J. T. Priestley
4:30 p.m.--Meeting of the Advisory Board and Board of Gover-
nors of the Alumni Association with the Board of Governors
of the Mayo Clinic--Board of Governors' Room, Mayo Clinic

Friday, October 25
Morning program, 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 m.
8:00 a.m. - 12:00 m.--Surgical clinics--See daily lists at Miss Fitz-
gerald's desk in Clinic and Alumni Headquarters.
8:00-10 a.m.--Medical rounds--The following physicians will be
making rounds or conducting conferences and will welcome
small groups of alumni.
Medical rounds--St. Mary's Hospital
Gastro-intestinal diseases__G. B. Eusterman and associates
Vascular diseases _________________N. W. Barker
Medical rounds--Worrall Hospital
Nephritis and hypertension _______________N. W. Binger
(continued on other side)
AC
LM
Medical rounds--Colonial Hospital
General medicine _________D. M. Masson and associates
Hepatic and biliary disease _____________H. R. Butt
10:00 a.m.-2:00 p.m.--Mayo Foundation House
Demonstration of current research in the Mayo Clinic and
Mayo Foundation.

Afternoon Session
Plummer Hall
2:00 p.m.--Business meeting.
2:30 p.m.--Sulfathiazole and related compounds ___A. E. Brown
and W. E. Herrell
Postoperative pneumonia _______________H. W. Schmidt
One stage resection for lesions of the colon___C. W. Mayo
Diagnosis and treatment of glossopharyngeal neural-
gia: motion picture of demonstration of surgical
technic ______________________George Baker
Surgical treatment of ununited fractures of the hip
___________________________M. S. Henderson

SOCIAL PROGRAM FOR MEETING OF THE
ALUMNI ASSOCIATION

Wednesday, October 23
4:00 p.m.--Tea for the ladies at the home of Dr. and Mrs.
C. W. Mayo, Mayowood,-(Transportation may be arranged
through Miss Fitzgerald.)
Open House for members of The Alumni Association, Fellows of
the Mayo Foundation and their wives at Mayo Foundation
House after Staff Meeting Wednesday evening.

Thursday, October 24
12:15 p.m.--Luncheon for members at the Hotel Kahler (guests
of the Mayo Clinic).
1:00 p.m.--Luncheon for the ladies at the home of Dr. and
Mrs. D. C. Balfour, 427 Sixth Avenue, S.W.
7:00 p.m.--Annual banquet for members and their wives at the
Hotel Kahler.
PERSONALS

Dr. Helmholz is in Washington, D. C., to attend
a meeting of the National Citizen's Committee of
the White House Conference on Children in a De-
mocracy.

Dr. Stafne will address a meeting of the alumni
of the University of Nebraska School of Dentistry
in Lincoln the end of the week; his subject is
“Dental diagnosis.”

Dr. Hench will be in Washington, Pennsylvania,
tomorrow to attend a dedication of the Lazear Me-
morial Building at Washington and Jefferson College;
he will be awarded an honorary degree.
